title: Medications That Treat Schizophrenia
author: Kim Painter

sections.heading: Medications for Schizophrenia
content: If you have schizophrenia, it's important to get treatment as quickly as possible. Medication is key, along with other types of care, such as psychotherapy , which is a kind of talk therapy, and social skills training.

But you have to be sure you take your medication. And that’s not always easy. Schizophrenia is a mental disorder that affects how a person acts, thinks, and feels. It can keep you from seeing the world in a normal way, which means you may not want to take your medication.
Schizophrenia causes many symptoms, including:
Doctors aren’t sure exactly what causes schizophrenia . There is no cure. So to treat it, a doctor will prescribe medications that can ease symptoms and prevent them from coming back.
Many different medications that ease delusions and other symptoms can be used for schizophrenia. (Photo Credit: Moment/Getty Images)
bullets: Hallucinations (seeing or hearing things that aren’t there)
Jumbled or confused thinking and speaking
Odd and random movements like strange posture
Trouble planning and carrying out activities

But you have to be sure you take your medication. And that’s not always easy. Schizophrenia is a mental disorder that affects how a person acts, thinks, and feels. It can keep you from seeing the world in a normal way, which means you may not want to take your medication.

Jumbled or confused thinking and speaking
Odd and random movements like strange posture
Trouble planning and carrying out activities

content_blocks.text: Doctors aren’t sure exactly what causes schizophrenia . There is no cure. So to treat it, a doctor will prescribe medications that can ease symptoms and prevent them from coming back.
Many different medications that ease delusions and other symptoms can be used for schizophrenia. (Photo Credit: Moment/Getty Images)

sections.heading: Antipsychotic Medications for Schizophrenia
content: The medications doctors prescribe most often for schizophrenia are called antipsychotics. They ease symptoms such as delusions and hallucinations.

These drugs work by changing how your brain uses chemicals such as dopamine and serotonin. These chemicals affect mood, movement, and the way you respond to experiences. You can get these medications during an episode to help relieve psychosis quickly and also take them long term to prevent symptoms.
You'll most likely have to take schizophrenia medication your entire life, even if your symptoms get better. You can take antipsychotics as a liquid, a pill, or as an injection.

If you think you might have trouble remembering to take medicine every day, you can try a shot you get from your doctor once or twice a month called a long-acting injectable antipsychotic medication (LAI). It works just as well as taking a daily pill.
Doctors will recommend which medication is best by considering:
bullets: How well it works on your symptoms
How easily you can get it
How often you have to take it

If you think you might have trouble remembering to take medicine every day, you can try a shot you get from your doctor once or twice a month called a long-acting injectable antipsychotic medication (LAI). It works just as well as taking a daily pill.
Doctors will recommend which medication is best by considering:
associated_bullets: How well it works on your symptoms
How easily you can get it
How often you have to take it

content: Your doctor may adjust your dosage over time and might change the medication you take, depending on how you respond. In some cases, your doctor will prescribe more than one kind of antipsychotic drug.

Antipsychotics work best on symptoms like hallucinations and delusions that have to do with your ability to tell what's real and what's not real. They may be less effective on symptoms like withdrawal from daily activities and lack of emotion.

sections.heading: Types of Antipsychotic Medications for Schizophrenia
content: There are two groups of antipsychotics. Doctors call the older group of medications “first-generation,” “typical,” or “conventional” antipsychotics. Some common ones are:
The later ones are called “second-generation” or “atypical” antipsychotics. They are the main drugs used for treating psychosis today. Examples of these medicines include:

content_blocks.text: There are two groups of antipsychotics. Doctors call the older group of medications “first-generation,” “typical,” or “conventional” antipsychotics. Some common ones are:
The later ones are called “second-generation” or “atypical” antipsychotics. They are the main drugs used for treating psychosis today. Examples of these medicines include:

content: A new antipsychotic, xanomeline-trospium (Cobenfy) , is harder to categorize. While most antipsychotics work within the dopamine system, this drug targets receptors in the brain's cholinergic system.

Note: Clozapine is the only FDA-approved medication for treating schizophrenia that is resistant to other treatments. Because it can have some extra side effects, it's typically prescribed only if you haven't responded to other antipsychotic medications. It's also approved for prevention of suicide in people with schizophrenia, so might be prescribed if your doctor believes you are at high risk for suicide, even if you haven't tried other drugs first.

It's also approved for prevention of suicide in people with schizophrenia, so might be prescribed if your doctor believes you are at high risk for suicide, even if you haven't tried other drugs first.

sections.heading: Side Effects of Antipsychotics
content: While the first-generation, older meds usually cost less, they can have different side effects than the newer antipsychotics. Some can cause higher levels of the hormone prolactin . This can affect sex drive, mood, menstrual cycles, and growth of breast tissue in both men and women.
One of the common side effects of many of the newer antipsychotics is weight gain. You may also have trouble keeping your blood sugar and cholesterol levels under control.

content_blocks.text: While the first-generation, older meds usually cost less, they can have different side effects than the newer antipsychotics. Some can cause higher levels of the hormone prolactin . This can affect sex drive, mood, menstrual cycles, and growth of breast tissue in both men and women.
One of the common side effects of many of the newer antipsychotics is weight gain. You may also have trouble keeping your blood sugar and cholesterol levels under control.

content: One of the more serious side effects from long-term use of both the older and newer medications is a movement disorder called tardive dyskinesia. It makes your facial, tongue, and neck muscles move uncontrollably and can be permanent.
While both older and newer antipsychotics can cause tardive dyskinesia, researchers believe that the odds are higher with the older antipsychotics.
Antipsychotics come with other side effects as well. You could have any of the following:
Be sure you see your doctor regularly while taking antipsychotic medication. And talk to your doctor if you have any concerns about side effects.

sections.heading: Add-on Treatments
content: Along with antipsychotic drugs, your doctor may prescribe another type of medication. Depending on your symptoms, they could give you a mood stabilizer or antidepressant .
We need more research about how effective these treatments are for schizophrenia, but many doctors try them.
They might prescribe these extra drugs for what's known as treatment-resistant schizophrenia. This means antipsychotics aren't helping with all your symptoms.

content_blocks.text: Along with antipsychotic drugs, your doctor may prescribe another type of medication. Depending on your symptoms, they could give you a mood stabilizer or antidepressant .
We need more research about how effective these treatments are for schizophrenia, but many doctors try them.
They might prescribe these extra drugs for what's known as treatment-resistant schizophrenia. This means antipsychotics aren't helping with all your symptoms.

sections.heading: Mood Stabilizers
content: Mood stabilizers balance your moods. This means you're less affected by depression, anxiety, or excitement.
Mood stabilizers include:
Their side effects include:
If your doctor gives you lithium, they'll do regular blood tests and watch for  kidney and thyroid problems it can cause.
bullets: Swelling in your eyes, face, mouth, throat, hands, feet, or lower legs

sections.heading: Antidepressants
content: Many people who have schizophrenia also have symptoms of depression . Doctors can treat these symptoms with antidepressants, which affect brain chemicals that are linked to emotions.
The most frequently prescribed types of antidepressants are called selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors or SSRIs. They include:
Some of the more common side effects of antidepressants are:

sections.heading: Schizophrenia Support
content: Schizophrenia can make it hard to stick to a medication plan. You'll need a strong support system.

Learn as much as you can about schizophrenia and encourage family members to do the same. Allow your loved ones to be part of the decision-making process with your doctor. Surrounding yourself with people who care about your well-being can help you cope with your illness and stick to your treatment plan.
When you start to take your medication for schizophrenia, you may feel better right away. But it may take up to 4 to 6 weeks before symptoms like hallucinations and delusions get better.
Be sure to keep taking it long enough for you and your doctor to know if it’s working. Sometimes it can take several tries to find out which medication works best.

In addition to medication and talk therapy, your treatment and support plans may include other kinds of help. These might include counseling on finding and keeping a job, social skills training, and help with issues like finding housing or dealing with legal problems.

sections.heading: Takeaways
content: Many different medications can help you reduce the symptoms of schizophrenia. Antipsychotic drugs are the main treatments, though they may be combined with other medications, along with talk therapy and other support. Medications for schizophrenia come with side effects, so you'll need to work with your doctor to find the ones that work best for you with the fewest side effects.

content_blocks.text: Many different medications can help you reduce the symptoms of schizophrenia. Antipsychotic drugs are the main treatments, though they may be combined with other medications, along with talk therapy and other support. Medications for schizophrenia come with side effects, so you'll need to work with your doctor to find the ones that work best for you with the fewest side effects.

sections.heading: Medications for Schizophrenia FAQ
content: What is the most popular medication for schizophrenia?

Treatment guidelines for U.S. doctors say schizophrenia treatment should start with an antipsychotic medication but don't single out any drug. Prescription trends may change over time, especially as new drugs become available. But a study conducted in the United States between 2005 and 2018 found that olanzapine, quetiapine, and risperidone were the antipsychotic drugs most often prescribed to adults with schizophrenia.
Can schizophrenia be cured without medication?

Schizophrenia can't be cured, but it can be managed with a combination of medication and other therapies. In many cases, people who stick to a treatment plan can have healthy relationships, keep jobs, and pursue other goals.

Prescription trends may change over time, especially as new drugs become available. But a study conducted in the United States between 2005 and 2018 found that olanzapine, quetiapine, and risperidone were the antipsychotic drugs most often prescribed to adults with schizophrenia.
Can schizophrenia be cured without medication?

Schizophrenia can't be cured, but it can be managed with a combination of medication and other therapies. In many cases, people who stick to a treatment plan can have healthy relationships, keep jobs, and pursue other goals.

sections.heading: How do antipsychotic medications work?
content: Doctors believe these medications for schizophrenia work by causing changes in your brain chemistry. Changes in a chemical called dopamine may be especially important because research suggests symptoms of psychosis can be caused by your brain making too much dopamine. Older antipsychotic medications may help by blocking dopamine receptors in your brain; newer versions block some receptors while activating others. The medications also seem to affect brain chemicals that are important for mood, such as serotonin, noradrenaline, and glutamate.
Do I need to take schizophrenia medication for a lifetime?

Treatment guidelines in the United States say that once you find an antipsychotic medication that works for you, you should stay on it to keep your symptoms manageable and prevent the return of your most disruptive symptoms. That can mean lifetime treatment. But research is continuing to look at whether some people might be able to manage schizophrenia with less medication, or without medication, at some point in their lives.

meta_description: Medications for schizophrenia have multiple side effects. Knowing the medication can help you recover faster and eliminate possible side effects like dystonia, tremors, and involuntary muscle contractions.
